name: Inguinal Hernia
steps:
1. Inspection (Patient Standing)

  • Exposure: Patient must stand. Expose from umbilicus to mid-thigh.
  • Observation: Identify the site (inguinal vs femoral), shape (pyriform vs globular), and extent (scrotal extension). Look for surgical scars.
  • Cough Impulse: Ask patient to turn head away and cough. Observe for an expansile impulse.

2. Palpation (Patient Standing)

  • Get Above the swelling: Palpate the root of the scrotum. If you cannot get above the swelling, it is an inguinoscrotal hernia. If you can, it is a primary scrotal swelling (e.g., hydrocele).
  • Palpate the Lump: Assess consistency (soft/gurgling = bowel; doughy = omentum), tenderness, and temperature.
  • Reducibility: Ask the patient to reduce the hernia themselves. If they cannot, attempt gentle taxis.
  • Deep Ring Occlusion Test: Reduce the hernia. Locate the deep inguinal ring (midpoint of the inguinal ligament: 1.5cm superior to the femoral pulse). Occlude it firmly with your thumb. Ask patient to cough.
    • Controlled (Hernia does not reappear): Indirect Inguinal Hernia (passes through deep ring).
    • Uncontrolled (Hernia reappears medial to thumb): Direct Inguinal Hernia (bulges through posterior wall/Hesselbach's triangle).

3. Palpation (Patient Lying)

  • Confirm Reducibility: If irreducible standing, re-attempt supine.
  • Testes: Palpate both testes to rule out atrophy or masses.

4. Auscultation

  • Bowel Sounds: Presence confirms enterocele (bowel content) vs omentocele.
ddx:
Differentiating Groin Lumps

Types
  • Indirect Inguinal Hernia: Passes through deep ring, travels down inguinal canal, often descends into scrotum. Controlled by deep ring pressure. (Congenital patent processus vaginalis).
  • Direct Inguinal Hernia: Bulges directly through Hesselbach's triangle (posterior wall weakness). Rarely enters scrotum. Not controlled by deep ring pressure. (Acquired weakness).
  • Femoral Hernia: Globular lump below the inguinal ligament and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Neck is inferior to the inguinal ligament. High risk of strangulation due to rigid borders (lacunar ligament).
  • Saphena Varix: Soft, compressible lump at the saphenofemoral junction. Exhibits a thrill on coughing (Cruveilhier's sign) and disappears instantly on lying down.

Anatomy

Anatomical Boundaries of Inguinal Canal:
- Anterior: External oblique aponeurosis.
- Posterior: Transversalis fascia (weak in direct hernia).
- Roof: Conjoint tendon (internal oblique + transversus abdominis).
- Floor: Inguinal ligament.
Hesselbach's Triangle: Boundaries are Inferior Epigastric vessels (Lateral), Rectus Abdominis border (Medial), and Inguinal Ligament (Inferior).
inv:
Routine

  • Clinical Diagnosis is usually sufficient.

Imaging

  • USG Groin: If diagnosis is uncertain or to distinguish from hydrocele/lymph node.
  • CT Abdomen: If strangulation or obstruction is suspected.
mgmt:
Surgical Management

  • Mesh Repair (Lichtenstein): Standard open tension-free repair.
  • Laparoscopic (TEP/TAPP): Indicated for bilateral or recurrent hernias to avoid scar tissue and for faster recovery.
  • Strangulation: Surgical emergency requiring resection of non-viable bowel.

name: Thyroid Status
steps:
1. Inspection (Anterior)

  • Water Swallow Test: Give patient a glass of water. Observe the neck as they swallow. A thyroid swelling will move up with the larynx (due to attachment via pretracheal fascia).
  • Tongue Protrusion: If a midline mass moves up on tongue protrusion, it is a Thyroglossal Cyst (attached to foramen cecum).
  • General Observation: Look for scars (Kocher’s incision), dilated veins (retrosternal obstruction), or redness.

2. Palpation (From Behind)

  • Thyroid Gland: Flex the patient's neck slightly to relax sternocleidomastoids. Palpate the isthmus and both lobes. Assess size, surface (smooth/nodular), consistency (soft/firm/hard), and tenderness.
  • Fixation: Ask patient to swallow while palpating to feel if the gland moves freely or is fixed to strap muscles (malignancy/thyroiditis).
  • Lymph Nodes: systematically examine levels I-VI.
  • Carotid Arteries: Check for Berry's Sign (carotid pulse displaced posteriorly by large goiter).
  • Trachea: Check for deviation.

3. Percussion & Auscultation

  • Percussion: Percuss over the manubrium. Dullness suggests retrosternal extension.
  • Auscultation: Listen over the lobes for a systolic bruit (pathognomonic of increased vascularity in Graves' disease).

4. Systemic Signs (Thyroid Status)

  • Hands: Pulse (Tachycardia/AF), Fine tremor (Paper test), Palmar erythema, Thyroid Acropachy (clubbing-like swelling in Graves'), Onycholysis (Plummer's nails).
  • Eyes: Exophthalmos (Proptosis - view from above), Lid Retraction (Dalrymple's sign - see sclera above iris), Lid Lag (Von Graefe's sign - lid slow to follow finger down), Ophthalmoplegia (H-test).
  • Legs: Pretibial Myxedema (waxy non-pitting edema in Graves').
  • Reflexes: Slow relaxing ankle jerks (Hypothyroidism).
ddx:
Diagnostic Patterns

Differentials
  • Graves' Disease (Primary Thyrotoxicosis): Diffuse smooth goiter + Thyroid Bruit + Exophthalmos + Pretibial Myxedema + Tremor.
  • Multinodular Goiter (MNG): Asymmetrical, nodular gland. Usually euthyroid. No bruit or eye signs.
  • Thyroid Carcinoma: Solitary, hard, irregular nodule. Rapid growth. Fixation to surrounding structures. Cervical lymphadenopathy. Hoarseness (Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve palsy).
  • Hashimoto's Thyroiditis: Firm, rubbery, diffuse goiter (bossellated). Often Hypothyroid.

Retrosternal Goiter

Suspect if the lower border of the thyroid is not palpable or if there is retrosternal dullness. Can cause Pemberton's Sign (facial congestion/stridor upon raising arms due to thoracic inlet obstruction).
inv:
Labs

  • TFTs: TSH, T3, T4.
  • Antibodies: Anti-TPO (Hashimoto's), TRAb (Graves').
  • Calcitonin: Medullary Thyroid Ca.

Imaging/Pathology

  • USG Neck: Assess solid vs cystic, calcifications.
  • FNAC: Bethesda Classification.
mgmt:
Complications of Thyroidectomy

  • Hemorrhage: Hematoma causing airway compression (Management: Remove sutures/clips immediately at bedside).
  • Hypocalcemia: Damage to parathyroid glands (Chvostek's/Trousseau's signs).
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve Palsy: Unilateral hoarseness; Bilateral airway obstruction.
  • Thyroid Storm: Life-threatening thyrotoxicosis crisis.

name: Varicose Veins
steps:
1. Inspection (Patient Standing)

  • Distribution: Inspect Medial Thigh/Calf (Long Saphenous Vein territory) and Posterior Calf (Short Saphenous Vein territory).
  • Skin Changes (CEAP C4): Look for Venous Eczema, Haemosiderin staining (brown pigmentation from RBC breakdown), Lipodermatosclerosis (inverted champagne bottle leg - fibrosis of fat), Atrophie Blanche (white scars).
  • Ulcers (CEAP C6): Typically in the 'gaiter area' (medial malleolus). Shallow, irregular sloping edges, granulation tissue base.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature/Tenderness: Check for hard, tender cords (Superficial Thrombophlebitis).
  • Cough Impulse: Palpate the Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) (2.5cm below and lateral to pubic tubercle). A thrill suggests a Saphena Varix.
  • Pit Test: Run fingers along the vein to detect defects in the deep fascia (sites of perforators).

3. Special Tests

  • Tap Test: Tap the SFJ while feeling the vein distally. A transmitted impulse implies a continuous column of blood (valvular incompetence).
  • Trendelenburg Test: Patient lies supine, leg elevated to empty veins. Occlude SFJ with thumb. Ask patient to stand.
    • Veins fill rapidly while occluded: Incompetence of perforators or Short Saphenous Vein (below the block).
    • Veins fill rapidly only after release: SFJ incompetence.
  • Perthes Test: Apply tourniquet below knee. Ask patient to perform heel raises. If veins become empty, deep veins are patent. If veins become turgid/painful, deep veins are occluded (Do not operate!).

4. Auscultation

  • Handheld Doppler: Listen over SFJ. Squeeze calf (augmentation) then release. A 'whoosh' lasting >0.5s on release indicates reflux.
ddx:
Key Signs & Definitions

Definitions
  • Varicose Veins: Dilated, tortuous superficial veins >3mm in diameter.
  • Saphena Varix: A dilation at the SFJ. It is soft, compressible, exhibits a cough impulse, and disappears completely on lying down (unlike a femoral hernia).
  • Lipodermatosclerosis: Chronic venous hypertension causes inflammation and fibrosis of the subcutaneous fat, constricting the lower leg.
inv:
Bedside

  • Handheld Doppler (Biphasic signal).
  • ABPI (To rule out arterial disease before compression).

Imaging

  • Duplex Ultrasound (Gold Standard): Maps anatomy and identifies reflux (>0.5s) at SFJ, SPJ, and perforators.
mgmt:
Indications for Intervention

Bleeding, Symptomatic (pain/heaviness), Recurrent Superficial Thrombophlebitis, Skin changes (C4-C6), Ulceration.

Treatment Options

  • Conservative: Class 2 graduated compression stockings.
  • Endothermal Ablation (Gold Standard): Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) or Endovenous Laser (EVLT) to burn/seal the vein.
  • Ultrasound-Guided Foam Sclerotherapy: Chemical sclerosis.
  • Open Surgery: High Tie (ligation of SFJ) and Strip (removal of LSV).

name: Peripheral Arterial Disease
steps:
1. Inspection

  • Trophic Changes: Look for shiny hairless skin, dystrophic (thick/ridged) nails, and muscle wasting (guttering).
  • Color: Pallor (ischemia), Rubor (reactive hyperemia/Buerger's sign), or Cyanosis.
  • Ulcers: Arterial ulcers are typically 'punched out', deep, painful, and located on pressure points (tips of toes, heel, metatarsal heads).
  • Gangrene: Dry (mummified/black) vs Wet (infected/oozing).
  • Buerger's Test: Elevate legs to 45° for 1-2 mins. Observe for pallor (Buerger's angle <20° = severe ischemia). Then hang legs dependent. Observe for 'sunset foot' (reactive hyperemia - deep red/purple).

2. Palpation

  • Temperature: Compare legs using the dorsal aspect of the hand. Ischemic limbs are cool.
  • Capillary Refill Time (CRT): Press on a digit for 5s. Normal return is <2s. Prolonged >2s indicates ischemia.
  • Pulses: Palpate systematically:
    • Femoral: Mid-inguinal point.
    • Popliteal: Deep in popliteal fossa, knee flexed to 30°.
    • Posterior Tibial: 2cm below and posterior to medial malleolus.
    • Dorsalis Pedis: Lateral to Extensor Hallucis Longus tendon.

3. Auscultation

  • Bruits: Listen over Femoral arteries, Aorta, and Renal arteries for turbulent flow.
ddx:
Clinical Features

Definitions
  • Intermittent Claudication: Cramping muscle pain (usually calf) on walking a fixed distance, relieved by rest within minutes. Reproducible.
  • Critical Limb Ischemia: Rest pain (burning pain at night, relieved by hanging leg out of bed) OR Tissue loss (Ulcer/Gangrene) present for >2 weeks.
  • Leriche Syndrome: Aortoiliac occlusion triad: 1. Buttock claudication, 2. Absent femoral pulses, 3. Erectile dysfunction.
inv:
Ankle Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

Ratio of ankle systolic pressure to brachial systolic pressure.
- >0.9: Normal.
- 0.5 - 0.9: Claudication.
- <0.5: Critical Limb Ischemia.
- >1.3: Calcified/Non-compressible vessels (Diabetes/CKD - falsely high).

Imaging

  • Duplex Ultrasound.
  • CT Angiogram.
mgmt:
Best Medical Therapy

  • Antiplatelet (Clopidogrel).
  • Statin (Atorvastatin 80mg).
  • BP control.
  • Smoking cessation.
  • Supervised Exercise program.

Intervention

  • Angioplasty: Balloon/Stenting.
  • Bypass grafting: e.g., Fem-Pop bypass (Vein graft preferred).
  • Amputation: If unsalvageable.

name: Abdominal Mass
steps:
1. Inspection

  • Distension: Check for the 5 F's (Fat, Fluid, Fetus, Flatus, Feces).
  • Visible Mass: Look for a mass moving with respiration or visible pulsation (AAA).
  • Scars: Identify previous surgical incisions (e.g., Kocher's, Midline, Rooftop).

2. Palpation

  • Superficial & Deep: Palpate all 9 quadrants. Define the mass: Site, Size, Shape, Surface (smooth/nodular), Edge (regular/irregular), Consistency (soft/hard), Tenderness, Pulsatility.
  • Organomegaly - Liver: Start RIF, move up to costal margin. Feel for edge. Assess span (scratch test/percussion).
  • Organomegaly - Spleen: Start RIF, move diagonally towards LUQ. A spleen moves inferomedially with inspiration.
  • Organomegaly - Kidney: Bimanual palpation (balloting). Place one hand behind loin and one anteriorly.

3. Percussion

  • Note: Percuss over the mass. Dullness indicates solid organ/fluid. Resonance indicates gas-filled bowel.
  • Shifting Dullness: Test for ascites (percuss from center to flank, patient rolls to side).

4. Auscultation

  • Bowel Sounds: Obstruction (tinkling) vs Ileus (absent).
  • Bruits: Renal artery (epigastric) or Hepatic (over liver - HCC).
ddx:
Differentiating Masses

Organomegaly Characteristics
  • Splenomegaly: Moves inferomedially with inspiration, has a palpable notch on anterior edge, unable to get above it, dull to percussion.
  • Enlarged Kidney: Moves inferiorly with inspiration, ballotable between hands, resonant to percussion (band of colonic resonance over anterior surface), can get above it.
  • Hepatomegaly: Moves inferiorly, cannot get above it, dull to percussion.

Etiology

Causes of Hepatomegaly:
- Smooth: Heart failure, Hepatitis, Fatty Liver.
- Craggy/Irregular: Metastases, Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC), Cirrhosis.
Causes of Splenomegaly: Massive (>10cm): Malaria, CML, Myelofibrosis. Moderate: Portal hypertension, Lymphoma, Hemolysis.
inv:
Routine

  • Urine Dip.
  • Blood: FBC, U/E, LFT, Coagulation.

Imaging

  • USG Abdomen: First line for organomegaly.
  • CT Abdomen/Pelvis: For characterization and staging.
mgmt:
Management Principles

  • Dependent on underlying cause.
  • Malignancy: Staging and Resection/Chemotherapy.
  • AAA: EVAR or Open Repair if >5.5cm.

name: Stoma Examination
steps:
1. Inspection

  • Site: Right Iliac Fossa (Ileostomy/Urostomy) vs Left Iliac Fossa (Colostomy).
  • Spout vs Flush:
    - Spouted: Ileostomy (to protect skin from enzymes) or Urostomy.
    - Flush: Colostomy (solid stool less irritant).
  • Lumen:
    - One opening: End stoma (permanent or Hartmann's).
    - Two openings (connected): Loop stoma (temporary/defunctioning).
    - Two openings (separated): Double barrel.
  • Effluent: Liquid/Green (Ileostomy), Solid/Brown (Colostomy), Urine (Urostomy).
  • Surrounding Skin: Erythema, Excoriation, Herniation (bulge), Prolapse (telescoping bowel), Retraction.

2. Palpation

  • Stoma: Gently palpate the opening (digital exam) to check patency and assess for stenosis (if appropriate).
  • Cough Impulse: Check for Parastomal Hernia (defect in rectus muscle).
  • Skin: Tenderness or induration.

3. Conclusion

  • "I would like to examine the rectum (to check for stump/tumor) and review the fluid balance chart (high output).".
ddx:
Stoma Types

Definitions
  • End Colostomy: LIF, Flush. Formed after Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) or Hartmann's procedure.
  • Loop Ileostomy: RIF, Spouted. Used to defunction a distal anastomosis (e.g., in Anterior Resection).
  • Urostomy (Ileal Conduit): RIF, Spouted. Continuous urine output. Formed after Radical Cystectomy.
inv:
Investigating Complications

  • Contrast Studies (Gastrografin): To check for obstruction, fistula, or leaks.
  • CT Abdomen: For parastomal hernia or recurrence of disease.
  • Endoscopy: Via stoma to check proximal bowel.
mgmt:
Complications


- Early: Necrosis (ischemia - black stoma), Retraction (tension), High Output (>1.5L/day -> dehydration/electrolyte loss).
- Late: Parastomal Hernia, Prolapse, Stenosis, Skin dermatitis.

Management of High Output Stoma

Restrict hypotonic fluids (water/tea), oral rehydration salts (St Mark's solution), Loperamide, Codeine, PPI.

name: Breast Lump
steps:
1. Inspection (Position 1: Arms by side)

  • Symmetry: Compare size, shape, and nipple level of both breasts.
  • Skin Changes: Look for Peau d'orange (edema), Dimpling, Puckering, Erythema, or Ulceration.
  • Nipple: Inversion, Discharge (blood/serous), Eczema (Paget's disease), Destruction/Deviation.

2. Inspection (Dynamic)

  • Arms above head: Lifts breasts to expose tethering to the pectoral fascia (cancer will hold skin back).
  • Hands on hips (press in): Contracts Pectoralis Major. Accentuates dimpling if the lump is fixed to the muscle.
  • Lean forward: For large pendulous breasts to expose the underside.

3. Palpation (Patient 45° or Flat)

  • Normal Breast: Use the flat of the hand in a spiral motion. Examine all 4 quadrants + Axillary tail.
  • The Lump: Assess the 3 D's: Dimensions, Depth, Definition. Assess Consistency (Hard/Soft) and Fixation (to skin or muscle).
  • Nipple: Squeeze gently to check for discharge.

4. Lymph Nodes (Patient Sitting)

  • Axillary: Support the patient's arm to relax the axilla. Palpate: Central, Lateral (humerus), Pectoral (anterior), Subscapular (posterior), and Apical nodes.
  • Supraclavicular: Palpate the fossa.
ddx:
Differential Diagnosis

Common Lumps
  • Fibroadenoma: 'Breast Mouse'. Firm, smooth, highly mobile, painless. Common in women <30y.
  • Breast Cyst: Smooth, fluid-filled, fluctuant (unless tense), tender. Common in perimenopausal women (35-50y).
  • Carcinoma: Hard, irregular, distinct edge, tethered to skin/muscle/nipple. Associated with bloody discharge and lymphadenopathy.
  • Fibrocystic Change: Generalized lumpiness, painful, varies with menstrual cycle.

Definitions

Peau d'orange: Cutaneous edema caused by blockage of subdermal lymphatics by cancer cells. The skin is swollen but hair follicles remain tethered, mimicking orange peel.
inv:
Triple Assessment (Gold Standard)

  1. Clinical Examination.
  2. Imaging: Mammogram (if >35y, as breast is less dense) OR Ultrasound (if <35y). MRI for screening high risk.
  3. Pathology: Core Biopsy (Histology - preferred for receptor status) OR FNAC (Cytology).
mgmt:
Surgical

  • WLE (Wide Local Excision): Breast conserving + Radiotherapy.
  • Mastectomy: If large tumor/multifocal.
  • Axilla: Sentinel Node Biopsy (standard) -> Axillary Clearance if positive.

Adjuvant

  • Chemo, Radiotherapy, Endocrine (Tamoxifen/Letrozole), Herceptin.

name: Subcutaneous Lump
steps:
1. Inspection

  • Site & Number: Single vs Multiple (Lipomatosis/Neurofibromatosis). Anatomical layer (Skin/Subcutaneous).
  • Skin Changes: Look for a Punctum (central black dot - Sebaceous Cyst), Scars, Erythema, or Pigmentation.

2. Palpation

  • Temperature & Tenderness: Inflammation/Abscess.
  • Surface & Edge: Smooth/Lobulated (Lipoma) vs Well-defined/Spherical (Cyst).
  • Consistency: Soft (Lipoma), Firm/Tense (Cyst), Hard (Calcified/Cancer).
  • Mobility (Plane):
    - Skin Fixation: Pinch skin over lump. If skin moves independently = Subcutaneous (Lipoma). If skin is tethered = Intradermal (Sebaceous Cyst).
    - Deep Fixation: Tense underlying muscle. If lump becomes fixed = Intramuscular/Bone. If mobile = Subcutaneous.
  • Slip Sign: Press edge of lump. If it slips away under the finger = Lipoma.
  • Fluctuation: Place two fingers on sides, press center. Fluid transmits pressure (Cyst/Abscess).

3. Special Tests

  • Transillumination: Shine torch. Light glows through fluid (Hydrocele, Ganglion, Epididymal Cyst). Lipomas typically do not transilluminate.
  • Compressibility: Disappears on pressure (Hemangioma/Varix).
ddx:
Common Lumps

Differentials
  • Lipoma: Benign tumor of fat. Soft, lobulated, subcutaneous (skin slides over it), positive slip sign. Occurs anywhere with fat.
  • Sebaceous (Epidermoid) Cyst: Distension of sebaceous gland. Firm, round, fixed to skin (cannot pinch skin over it), often has a central punctum. Contains foul cheesy keratin.
  • Ganglion: Cystic degeneration of synovial sheath. Dorsum of wrist/hand. Transilluminates.
  • Dermoid Cyst: Congenital. Midline (brow/nose). Deep to skin.

Transillumination

Positive in Hydrocele, Epididymal cyst, Cystic Hygroma, Ganglion.
inv:
Imaging

  • Ultrasound: Distinguishes solid (lipoma) from cystic (ganglion) and assesses depth/vascularity.
  • MRI: For deep soft tissue sarcomas.

Pathology

  • FNAC: For cytology.
  • Excision Biopsy: Definitive diagnosis.
mgmt:
Differentiation & Management

Differentiation: A sebaceous cyst is fixed to the skin (punctum) while a lipoma is mobile under the skin (slip sign).
Management:
- Lipoma: Conservative or Excision for cosmesis/pain.
- Sebaceous Cyst: Excision biopsy (elliptical incision) to remove the entire capsule. Rupture leads to recurrence and infection.
